docs.lead_paragraph: The ultimate tribute for doctors is to have an ailment, microbe, instrument or anatomical area named after them, and medical journals and textbooks are sprinkled with hundreds of such eponyms. Many are rewards for providing the first description of a disease or type of cell, focusing new attention on a previously obscure condition or group of symptoms, or devising an instrument adopted by others. But occasionally a tribute proves embarrassing because of an inadequate search into medical history or the background of the honoree. And new information can always change the picture.

headline.main: Experts Re-examine Dr. Reiter, His Syndrome and His Nazi Past

docs.abstract: New attention is being paid to Hans Conrad Reiter, German doctor after whom Reiter's syndrome is named and whose his involvement in Nazi atrocities now appears deeper than previously known; two arthritis experts at University of California at Los Angeles add further evidence of Reiter's role as a Nazi who helped plan and approve 'human experiments' in concentration camps; they say Reiter may have earned highest marks for his teaching and service to community, but ask if a war criminal 'should be rewarded with eponymous distinction'; photos of Reiter, and other individuals after whom diseases were named (M)
docs.snippet: The ultimate tribute for doctors is to have an ailment, microbe, instrument or anatomical area named after them, and medical journals and textbooks are sprinkled with hundreds of such eponyms. Many are rewards for providing the first description of a...

keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.lead_paragraph: When a person dies in Detroit and no one claims the body, an interesting thing may happen to it. The cadaver may wind up being donated to the University of Michigan Medical School's plastination laboratory and turned into an eternity-ready version of itself. Plastination is the process of taking organic tissue -- a rosebud, say, or a human head -- and replacing the water in it with a liquid silicone polymer. The polymer hardens after the application of a catalyst, permanently preserving the deceased entity.

headline.main: A New Student Aid: Plastic Body Parts, Made From the Real Things

docs.abstract: University of Michigan Medical School's plastination laboratory plastinates, for first time in North America, an entire human body; plastination is process of taking organic tissue and replacing water in it with liquid silicone polymer; polymer hardens after application of catalyst, permanently preserving diseased entity; photo of human heart that has been plastinated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With all the concern most parents express about the safety of their children, it is surprising -- no, shocking -- that so many parents are so casual about a proven safety measure that could make a life-or-death difference: the consistent use of proper child restraints in motor vehicles, especially for children who are too old for infant and child safety seats and too young for adult seat belts. In New York State, parents cannot take a newborn home from the hospital in a car without a proper car safety seat.

headline.main: Children's Safety Often Neglected in Cars

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on children's safety in cars; find that it is surprising, even shocking, that so many parents are so casual about proven safety measure that could make life-or-death difference: consistent use of proper child restraints in motor vehicles, especially for children who are too old for infant and child safety seats and too young for adult seat belts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: I never dreamed of running off to join the circus. A childhood trip to the Big Top was thrilling but when the spotlight hit the daring young men and women on the flying trapeze, I hardly imagined myself hurtling through space in a sequined skirt. I like my feet firmly planted on the ground. How, then, do I manage to be among the first in line when the circus class comes to town? Certainly, boredom with the same old step aerobics and stair-climber is a compelling motive. Mostly, though, I wanted to impress my kids with some cool moves. And over the last few months, sports clubs, ever seeking newer and more unusual offerings, have begun to offer classes in circus skills.

headline.main: Daring to Be a Daredevil, in Circus Class

docs.abstract: Sports clubs offer classes in circus skills like trapeze, juggling and gymnastics; photos (M)
